bestBHT.bht: A tempestuous wind called Euroclydon, resembling a typhonic wind, arises and causes a whirling of the clouds due to opposing currents of air. This violent and turbulent wind exhibits the characteristics of a hurricane or whirlwind, agitating and exciting the waves. Its direction is a combination of the Greek word for east wind and the Latin word for northeast. As the storm rages for many days, it tosses the ship back and forth, reminding us of the power and unpredictability of nature.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: a tempestuous—'typhonic' wind—that is, like a typhon or tornado, causing a whirling of the clouds, owing to the meeting of opposite currents of air.
called Euroclydon—The true reading appears to be Euro-aquilo, or east-northeast, which answers all the effects here ascribed to it.
Albert Barnes: A tempestuous wind - Turbulent - violent - strong.
The most probable supposition is, that it denotes 'a wind not blowing steadily from any quarter, but a hurricane, or wind veering about to different quarters.'
The name euroclydon is derived probably from two Greek words, εῦρος euros, 'wind,' and κλύδων kludōn, 'a wave'; so called from its agitating and exciting the waves.
Marvin Vincent: The verb ballw is also used intransitively in the sense of to fall; thus Homer (" Iliad, "11, 722), of a river falling into the sea."
A tempestuous wind [ανεμος τυφωνικος] . Lit., a typhonic wind.
The best texts read Eujrakulwn, Euraquilo : i.e., between Eurus, 'the E.S.E. wind,' and Aquilo, 'the north-wind, or, strictly, N. 1/3 E.'
Philip Schaff: How suddenly violent changes may take place when we least expect them, and when we have thought that already we have ‘gained our purpose’!
The meaning is that the storm came ‘down from the island.’ The land here is very high, and the gale suddenly swept down one of the gullies among the mountains, in a south-westerly direction.

Whatever may be our conclusion in this matter, two things are clear, first, either word shows that the gale blew more or less from the east; while, secondly, the fact that it came ‘down from’ the island, and drove the ship to the southward (see below), shows that it blew more or less from the north.
Archibald T. Robertson: The Ευρακυλων has not been found elsewhere. Blass calls it a hybrid word compounded of the Greek ευρος (east wind) and the Latin αθυιλο (northeast).
Here the name gives the direction of the wind.
John Gill: The wind Typhon never blew in the northern parts."
This storm of wind was a settled and lasting one, it continued many days."
This wind may very well be thought to be the same which is called Typhon, and is by writers represented as a very tempestuous one, as a sort of whirlwind or hurricane, a violent storm.
John Wesley: There arose against it — The south wind; a tempestuous wind, called in those parts Euroclydon.
This was a kind of hurricane, not carrying them any one way, but tossing them backward and forward.
Furious winds are now called levanters, and blow in all directions from the northeast to the southeast.

bhtAttempts.bht: In this verse, a tempestuous wind called Euroclydon arises, resembling a typhonic wind and causing a whirling of the clouds due to opposing currents of air. The name Euroclydon indicates the direction of the wind, being a hybrid word combining the Greek word for east wind and the Latin word for northeast. This violent and turbulent wind blows from the east but also varies in direction. It is a hurricane-like storm, agitating and exciting the waves. The storm continues for many days, tossing the ship backward and forward. This sudden and unexpected change demonstrates how violent storms can arise when we least expect them, reminding us of the power and unpredictability of nature.

A tempestuous wind called Euroclydon, resembling a typhonic wind, arises and causes a whirling of the clouds. This wind is described as turbulent, violent, and strong, with the ability to suddenly change directions. It is a hurricane-like storm, agitating and exciting the waves. The storm continues for many days, tossing the ship backward and forward. This sudden and unexpected change demonstrates how violent storms can arise when we least expect them, reminding us of the power and unpredictability of nature.
